seo.title: Fibonacci Retracements & Elliott Waves – Graphical Analysis Guide | Qption
seo.description: Learn Fibonacci Retracements and Elliott Wave Theory: key levels (23.6%, 38.2%, 50%, 61.8%, 78.6%), plotting, S/R, continuation vs reversal, impulse/corrective waves, and combining with MAs & trend lines.
seo.keywords: Fibonacci retracement, Elliott Wave Theory, graphical analysis, technical analysis, support and resistance, impulse waves, corrective waves, Fibonacci levels, moving averages, trend lines, price targets, risk management, Qption

ld.headline: Fibonacci Retracements & Elliott Waves – Graphical Analysis Guide
ld.description: Learn Fibonacci Retracements and Elliott Wave Theory in graphical analysis.

page.title: Fibonacci Retracements and Elliott Waves in Graphical Analysis

video.aria: Fibonacci retracements help identify potential support/resistance by applying Fibonacci ratios to price charts.

fibOverview.i1: Fibonacci retracements are a popular tool to mark potential support/resistance using Fibonacci ratios.
fibOverview.i3: They help locate entries/exits by observing price reactions at these levels.

s1.t: From low→high in uptrends (or high→low in downtrends), creating horizontal lines at Fibonacci levels.

s2.t: Levels may act as reaction zones where price reverses or consolidates.

s3.t: If price holds a level, the trend often resumes, offering potential entries.

s4.t: A decisive break beyond a key level can hint at a trend change.

t1.i1: Confluence with trend lines strengthens level validity.
t1.i2: Look for alignment as high-confluence zones.

t2.i1: When a level aligns with an MA, reliability improves.
t2.i2: 50/200 MAs with Fib levels often mark strong reactions.

fibProsCons.h: Benefits and Limitations of Fibonacci Retracements

p1.t: Clear levels to plan entries, exits, and stops.

p2.t: Works well with trend lines and MAs for validation.

c1.t: Not standalone; relying only on Fib can produce false signals in volatility.

ewOverview.i1: Studies price as waves to infer direction via cycles/patterns.
ewOverview.i3: Used to anticipate continuation, reversals and retracements.

s1.t: Five waves in trend direction; 1,3,5 with trend; 2,4 corrective.

s2.t: Three waves (A-B-C) against the primary trend.

s3.t: Identify patterns to time trend continuation or endings.

s4.t: Fib ratios frequently align with waves (e.g., 2/4 retracements, 5 extensions).

t1.i1: Impulses show trend strength/direction; corrections mark pullbacks.
t1.i2: Enter with impulses; use corrections to anticipate retracements.

t2.i1: Fib ratios appear within waves (2/4 retrace; 5 extends).
t2.i2: Blend Fib retracements with counts to project targets/turns.

ewProsCons.h: Benefits and Limitations of Elliott Waves
ewProsCons.p1: Benefit: Structured lens for market cycles and reversals.
ewProsCons.p2: Benefit: Pairs well with Fibonacci for targets and stops.
ewProsCons.c1: Limitation: Can be complex/subjective; counts vary.
ewProsCons.c2: Limitation: Mislabeling waves leads to poor predictions.
